title: VC Daily: The Theranos Effect on Silicon Valley
text:
And now on to the news...

Top News

Beyond Theranos. Blood-testing startups are thriving, undeterred by any fallout from the collapse of Theranos Inc., a startup that once sought to revolutionize the industry, WSJ Pro's Brian Gormley reports. A federal jury on Monday convicted Theranos founder Elizabeth Holmes on charges that she conducted a yearslong fraud scheme against investors. Ms. Holmes testified at trial that she never intended to mislead anyone, and is likely to appeal. Theranos had said it could test for a range of health conditions with a few drops of blood, but unraveled after a series of Wall Street Journal articles in 2015 and 2016 called its proprietary technology into question.

Nonetheless, venture-capital interest in blood-testing startups has continued despite Theranos's demise, as investors have evaluated individual companies on their merit and potential to make disease detection simpler and more accessible.

Last year, several startups raised venture financings and others were acquired.

3%

The quits rate for workers in November, returning to a record rate last seen in September, the Labor Department said. (WSJ)

TPG Launches IPO Roadshow Seeking Valuation Around $9.5 Billion

Private-equity firm TPG launched its roadshow pitch to investors Tuesday, seeking a valuation as high as $9.5 billion in its initial public offering, moving into the final stretch of a process that has been months in the making, The Wall Street Journal reports. The firm and some of its shareholders are aiming to sell shares at between $28 and $31 apiece, it said in a regulatory filing Tuesday. TPG—based in Fort Worth, Texas, and San Francisco—plans to price its offering next Wednesday and list shares the following day, although the timing could change, according to people familiar with the matter.

Mainstream Lenders Dabble in Crypto Outside the U.S.

Mainstream banks outside the U.S. are sampling cryptocurrencies, offering customers ways to invest and store bitcoin and other digital assets, WSJ reports. Banco Bilbao Vizcaya Argentaria SA —Spain's second-largest lender by assets, with operations in Latin America and Turkey—allows customers to hold, buy and sell bitcoin and ether through a digital account. Australia's largest bank, Commonwealth Bank of Australia, has also launched a pilot program to offer similar services. In Germany, a group of savings banks, which together serve 50 million of the country's 80 million people, said it is considering offering cryptocurrency wallets. If the group proceeds, the move would be a significant step toward acceptance for crypto in a country that is ultraconservative with money.

Newsletter Special

The global venture market nearly doubled in 2021, according to research firm Crunchbase Inc.

Private companies raised $642.9 billion in venture capital in 2021, up from $335.4 billion the prior year. The number of deals increased just 6% year over year to about 32,058 in 2021.

Dollars flowing into both early- and late-stage deals increased nearly two-fold, according to Crunchbase. Crunchbase now counts about 1,148 companies globally with a value of more than $1 billion each.

Startups in the financial services sector attracted the greatest amount of venture dollars last year, followed by the healthcare, e-commerce and transportation sectors, Crunchbase said.

In terms of global regions, North America led by total dollars invested, with $330 billion, followed by Asia, with $165 billion, and Europe, with $116 billion. Latin America, however, showed the fastest growth in venture investments, which increased by about 300% year over year to about $19.6 billion.

The data is based on deals reported through Jan. 3, and totals may increase as more data comes through, according to the data provider.

—Yuliya Chernova

Industry News

Funds

Israeli investor StageOne Ventures raised $235 million for its fourth fund. The new vehicle consists of a primary fund of $150 million focusing on seed investments, along with $85 million allotted for follow-on investments in existing portfolio companies. Recent StageOne exits include Epsagon and Apolicy, acquired by Cisco and Sysdig, respectively.

Exits

Google acquired cybersecurity startup Siemplify for an undisclosed amount. New York- and Israel-based Siemplify, which will join Google Cloud's security team, was backed by investors including Georgian, 83North, G20 Ventures and Jump Capital.

ServiceTitan, a provider of software for field service businesses, will expand into pest control and lawn care with its agreement to purchase FieldRoutes. Terms weren't disclosed. Backers of ServiceTitan include Bessemer Venture Partners, Iconiq Growth, Index Ventures, Tiger Global Management and T. Rowe Price.

Corvus Insurance, a commercial insurance technology provider, acquired cyber underwriting platform Tarian Underwriting Limited from insurance industry venture firm Beat Capital Partners. Terms weren't disclosed. Boston-based Corvus was founded in 2017, and counts Bain Capital Ventures, Insight Partners, Aquiline Capital Partners and FinTLV Ventures as investors.

New Money

Human Security Inc., a New York-based startup that provides protection against bot attacks and fraud, secured a $100 million growth investment. Led by WestCap Group, the funding included participation from NightDragon and others.

StoreDot, a Israeli provider of battery charging technology for electric vehicles, held the first close of its Series D round of up to $80 million. Vietnamese electric vehicle manufacturer VinFast led the funding, which included support from bp ventures and Golden Energy Global Investment.

Liquid Death, a Santa Monica, Calif.-based startup that sells water in aluminum cans, raised $75 million in Series C funding, giving the company a $525 million valuation. Science Ventures led the round, which included participation from investors including PowerPlant Partners and Nomad Ventures.

WEKA, a Campbell, Calif.-based data platform for AI workloads, picked up a $73 million investment. Lead investor Hitachi Ventures was joined by Hewlett Packard Enterprise, Nvidia, Micron Ventures, Cisco, MoreTech Ventures, Ibex Investors and Key 1 Capital in the round.

Zenlayer Inc., an edge cloud services provider, grabbed additional Series C funding from MDI Ventures, bringing the round total to $62 million.

Metaversal, a Miami-based combination venture studio and investment firm focused on NFTs, closed a $50 million Series A round. CoinFund and Foxhaven Asset Management led the investment, which included additional support from Collab+Currency, Digital Currency Group, Franklin Templeton, Narwhal Ventures, NGC Ventures, Rockaway Blockchain Fund, Theta Blockchain Ventures and others.

Xage, a Palo Alto, Calif.-based cybersecurity startup, nabbed $30 million in Series B financing. Piva led the investment, which included support from Momenta, Valor Equity Partners, OurCrowd, March Capital, City Light Capital, Saints Capital and Saudi Aramco Energy Ventures. Piva's Mark Gudiksen and Momenta's Michael Dolbec will join the company's board.

Prevedere, a provider of predictive analytics technology based in Columbus, Ohio and Sunnyvale, Calif., completed a $25 million funding round. Norwest Venture Partners led the financing, which included contributions from Workday Ventures, M12, JobsOhio, Gaingels and Latitude Ventures.

Livepeer Inc., a New York-based decentralized video transcoding network built on the Ethereum blockchain, landed $20 million in Series B1 financing from new investor Tiger Global Management, along with existing backers. Previous investors in the company include Northzone Ventures, Coinbase Ventures, CoinFund and 6th Man Ventures.

Whitebox, a Baltimore-based e-commerce marketing and fulfillment technology startup, added $20 million in funding. Led by Delta-v Capital, the round included participation from Noro-Moseley Partners and TDF Ventures.

Cion Digital, a software-as-a-service blockchain orchestration platform, was seeded with a $12 million investment. Green Visor Capital and 645 Ventures led the round, which saw participation from Cota Capital, Epic Ventures, Hourglass Capital Partners, BAT Ventures, Greycroft and Ulu Ventures.

BlockSpaces Inc., a Tampa, Fla.-based blockchain business integration platform, closed a $5.8 million seed round. Leadout Capital led the investment, with General Partner Steve Brownlie joining the board.

Tech News

Fanatics pried baseball cards from Topps. Now Fanatics is buying Topps.

Tencent sells roughly $3 billion of its stake in Singapore's Sea

Bloomberg Media CEO Justin Smith steps down to found news startup

Financial services firms aim for network modernization in 2022

BlackBerry die-hards struggle with final blow
